Okay, let’s talk HeroCon. 

Look around, and you’ll see a lot of discrimination—against people whose Quirk is debilitating, against people whose Quirks scare us, against people who have trouble controlling their Quirk, against people who don’t have a Quirk at all. It’s easy to feel alone in a sea of discrimination.

Enter HeroCon:X. 

 

A social media fic following Deku post-graduation.

Does anyone else find it ironic that Deku and All Might get along so well? I mean, All Might was forced to retire by a guy with tons of Quirks, and now here’s the former Symbol of Peace mentoring a hero with six Quirks?
I mean, does ANYONE else question this? The Quirk to have more than one Quirk is unheard of, and here’s a villain and a hero with the same Quirk and nobody is concerned? 
We’ve all seen the conspiracy videos about Deku being All Might’s secret child, but we know next to nothing about the villain at Kamino Ward except how he SHARES THE SAME QUIRK AS DEKU.
Quirk heritage is pretty straightforward. The child usually gets some variant of the parents. The evidence is in your faces.
Deku is not All Might’s secret child. Not by a long shot.

AnalysisOverloadOkay guys, buckle down. Today we’re talking about all the flaws in the heroics system.
I’ve made an itemized list. It’s 33 points long. If that’s too much for you, the tl:dr is as following: heroics has turned into a popularity contest and a political game instead of a system where heroes focus on helping people.
Here goes.

Read more

Nejire-Chan-foreverSo you’re saying Stain was right?
AnalysisOverloadGood question. Completely, absolutely not. Stain said “the hero system is messed up so I’m going to kill imperfect heroes.” I’m saying “the hero system is messed up so we need to do better at grassroots compassion, and we need to change the political landscape so it values people’s lives more.”
Killing people is almost never the answer. Killing people simply because the system they learned to adapt to is flawed? That’s definitely not the answer.

 #I get compared to Stain more often than I like #but he’s Wrong #killing people who don’t measure up isn’t a good way to increase selflessness in a system #analyses #stain #heroics

Deku just got out of the hospital, and we’re wandering the streets. Nobody notices him, since put this guy in a hoodie and somehow nobody pays attention to him? His whole body language changes and stuff, he looks like a whole different person. Not sure how he does that.

[rustling and banging, then a flood of light]

. . .
 
Shinsou had accused him of being overly dramatic. And sure, it sent the whole crowd crazy whenever he came to his panel in cosplay, particularly since several dozen of them had interacted with him throughout the con. 
But Izuku knew it was important for his fans to get to interact with him, not as some untouchable Number One, but as a equal fan. And today—today was going to be different.
Today, his cosplay as a Quirkless person was going to draw many of the questions that were always left on the cutting room floor of any interview he did.
Today, there was going to be a reckoning—a fierce one, a kind one, a necessary one.
There was a roar, giant to the point of vast, as he stepped onstage. The lights went blinding for endless seconds, sweeping across the stage, before fading back. 
He had requested, from his very first hero con, that the lights never be bright enough to make it so he couldn’t see everyone in the audience. The people were, after all, why he was there.
The roar slowly died off, tinged with confusion and chatter. Izuku knew full well why. In all his years, he had never cosplayed as anyone other than a hero.
“Hi, everyone,” he called out, clicking on the handheld microphone. “I guess you’re wondering why I cosplayed as a Quirkless person.”
And the roar was back.
Izuku settled more firmly in his skin and waited for it to quiet off. 
“As I’m sure many of you know,” he said, projecting his voice to the very back corners, “this hero con is about acceptance and inclusion. I know from personal experience that one of the hardest things to do is include people who aren’t like us. Let me tell you something the media companies wish I wouldn’t share.”
A buzz. Izuku had framed his words like a scandal, and everyone wanted to be the first to hear it.
Deep breath in. Deep breath out. Make eye contact with as many people as possible. 
“My first year on the job, there was something I brought up in every interview I did. In every case, it never made it to the final broadcast. I could have done this on live TV, but that always ran the risk of the interviewer dismissing the subject. I’ve been waiting for a time to talk about this where I have full control of the conversation. Are you ready?”
An affirmative shout. 
“I was Quirkless until right before UA,” he said, and the room went still. “I know what it’s like to be a societal reject, and I’m making sure that we don’t make people feel unwanted going forward.” 
Now, to break the script completely.
“Can I talk for a moment?” he asked, dropping his voice into something quieter, something softer, letting the microphone do all the hard work of projecting his voice. “Can I talk as Midoriya Izuku instead of Deku?”
A hush, stronger than the roar, settled in.
“It was really hard, growing up Quirkless,” he said. “People don’t believe in you very much, not when you don’t have a superpower.” He took a breath. It shook only a little. “I knew I wanted to be a hero from really early on. At first, I just wanted to be like All Might. Don’t we all?” A laugh, quickly cut off, circled the room.
“But then,” Izuku said, “I found I wanted to be a hero because I saw that there were a lot of people hurting, like me. Some of them were Quirkless. Some of them weren’t. Truth is, you can have any sort of Quirk and still be hurting. I wanted to help all the hurting people, and so I said I’d become a hero. That is my mission in life, to help people. I wanted to come here today to say that helping people is so important, and you don’t have to be a hero to do it. There’s—there’s this myth, that you can only do cool, important stuff if you’re a hero. That’s not true. Some of the best people I know aren’t heroes to anyone except for me.”
He was tearing up, now. He had enough practice leashing it that he could have suppressed it, but he didn’t. People needed to see that this was important to him. 
“I brought one of my best friends, Jazz, with me today. She’s amazing. She’s wise and she’s brave and she’s willing to face the world with kindness. She’s also Quirkless.”
Chatter, now. People started twisting in their chairs, looking for Jazz. Izuku could barely see her from here, hands hiding her face, shoulders shaking.
“I want people to know that your Quirk doesn’t determine your worth. Not even your actions determine your worth. You are all worth so, so much.” Tears rolled down his face, quiet and determined. “Every last one of you is worth the world. That’s what I came here to say. Thank you.”
He met Jazz’s eyes above the crowd.
And her smile was like daylight.
